Line 103: Line 103:
===IPO and culture===
===IPO and culture===
Many people have suggested that after Google's IPO their culture will not be able to stay so "fun" and focused on the future.[http://www.wired.com/news/business/0,1367,63241,00.html?tw=wn_story_related] [http://www.ciol.com/content/news/2004/104043001.asp] The company may be required to answer to shareholders who will want the company to cut back on employee benefits and to focus on short term advances. Also, it may be hard to maintain a collegial atmosphere when approximately 1,000 (30%) of the employees are paper-millionaires. In a report given to potential investors, co-founders Sergey Brin and Larry Page promised that the IPO would not change the company's culture. Later Mr. Page said, "We think a lot about how to maintain our culture and the fun elements." So far, they appear to have been successful.
Many people have suggested that after Google's IPO their culture will not be able to stay so "fun" and focused on the future.[http://www.wired.com/news/business/0,1367,63241,00.html?tw=wn_story_related] [http://www.ciol.com/content/news/2004/104043001.asp] The company may be required to answer to shareholders who will want the company to cut back on employee benefits and to focus on short term advances. Also, it may be hard to maintain a collegial atmosphere when approximately 1,000 (30%) of the employees are paper-millionaires. In a report given to potential investors, co-founders Sergey Brin and Larry Page promised that the IPO would not change the company's culture. Later Mr. Page said, "We think a lot about how to maintain our culture and the fun elements." So far, they appear to have been successful.
  +   +
==Acquisitions==
  +
Google Acquisitions
  +   +
Feb 2001: Deja (the Usenet archive, not the company) acquired, later to become part of the re-launched Google Groups [http://groups.google.com/googlegroups/deja_announcement.html].
  +   +
Sep 2001: Google acquired Outride Inc. [http://www.google.com/press/pressrel/outride.html].
  +   +
Feb 2003: Google acquired Pyra Labs, a web logging provider [http://www.google.com/corporate/timeline.html].
  +   +
Apr 2003: Neotonic Software was acquired as part of Google's plan to bring its CRM technology in house [http://www.searchenginejournal.com/index.php?p=621].
  +   +
Apr 2003: Applied Semantics was acquired [http://www.appliedsemantics.com].
  +   +
Sep 2003: Kaltix was acquired to develop and launch Google Personal [http://www.clickz.com/news/article.php/3085921].
  +   +
OCt 2003: Sprinks was acquired to enhance Google's Adwords and AdSense program [http://www.searchnewz.com/searchnewz-12-20031105GoogleAcquiresSprinks.html].
  +   +
Oct 2003: Google acquired Genius Labs, another web logging provider [http://www.bizstone.com/archive/2003_10_01_archive.html#106553958799049227].
  +   +
Apr 2004: Ignite Logic was acquired [http://battellemedia.com/archives/000653.php].
  +   +
Jun 2004: Google made a $10M investment into partial ownership of Baidu [http://english.people.com.cn/200406/16/eng20040616_146493.html].
  +   +
Jul 2004: Picasa was acquired to provide picture management tools to Blogger [http://www.google.com/press/pressrel/picasa.html].
  +   +
Oct 2004: Keyhole was acquired to provide the core mapping capabilities in Google Maps and Google Earth [http://www.google.com/press/pressrel/keyhole.html].
  +   +
Mar 2005: Web analytics tools provider Urchin software was acquired [http://www.google.com/intl/en/press/pressrel/urchin.html].
  +   +
Between Sept and Dec 2004, Google revealed in its annual [http://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1288776/000119312505065298/d10k.htm 10-K filing] that it had acquired 2 Silcon Valley start-up companies: ZipDash and Where2. The technology provided by ZipDash was used to develop and launch Google Ride Finder. Where2 was a mapping software provider.
  +   +
May 2005: DodgeBall was acquired [http://www.dodgeball.com/aboutus_dball_google.php].
